ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The definition of environmental justice and numerous case studies that helped me understand environmental justice issues in our past and present world.

This course is a great introduction to the Yale Environmental Studies department and to Yale in general. Professor Fotos does a great job of making sure you become accustomed with all facets of Yale such as the library resources, the film archive, the Beinecke, Dwight Hall, etc. The field trips to these various places made the class very enjoyable. Also, a great writing credit -- we learned about the extensive writing resources Yale has to help you with writing, and the writing assignments were well structured to explore different areas of academic writing.
This course provided good writing and research skills that can be used in future courses.
I learned about the definition of Justice, different types of justice, case studies globally about environmental injustice, and how to write more concisely.
I learned about environmental justice case studies in North America, South America, Europe, and Africa, as well as how to craft an annotated bibliography and its accompanying memo.
I feel like I didnt develop a lot of stuff that I didnt already know. I feel like I learned where to go for certain resources, which is a great skill.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This course helped me as a writer to really think about the power of even one sentence and to carefully evaluate the value of each word in my work. Another strenght: the variety of case studies

Could be improved by taking a more international context as well (right now very US oriented).
Very interactive class, great seminar discussions, and awesome field trips and guest speakers
Very Disorganized; Hard to plan via the syllabus as the professor would change assignments and projects on the fly
This course is structured around skill building instead of just completing assignments, which provided useful skills for future academic endeavors.

Strength: new case study every class was a good structure, lots of relevant field trips/speakers, short word limit on assignments helped my writing be more concise

Weakness: class not always structured, rubric/instructions for writing assignments not entirely clear

A strength of this course is the diversity of the reading material, both in terms of geographical areas covered and types of sources studied. We read everything from scientific studies to journalism articles. I also really enjoyed all of the guest speakersthey all provided complementary but different perspectives on issues of environmental justice. The main weakness of the course was a lack of clarity regarding expectations for the writing assignments, and few writing workshop opportunities considering that this was a WR credit.
I feel like it wasnt very organized and I didnt receive clear guidelines for assignments or feedback.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if interested in environmental justice and in environmental studies in general too. It's a great course to take even if your major is the complete opposite, as long as your interested about the world, justice, policy, ethical issues and so on.
highly recommend this class (especially with Professor Fotos). great first year seminar and wonderful introduction to Yale's academic environent
Probably not
This course is a very good intro for students who are exploring the EVST major and want to experience courses in this field of study.
Yes! Great intro to environmental studies (BA), take if youre interested in majoring or just want to learn more

I would recommend it after it has been offered a few more times. Since this was the first time the course was offered, the syllabus kept changing and it felt like we rushed some of the writing assignments. There was also a lack of clarity regarding the weight of each assignment.
Not really because I didnt learn very much and wasnt very engaged the entire time. The Professor is very kind, but I dont think I gained a lot from this class.
